reviewText:
Favorite FPS overall. I still prefer it to Red Orchestra 2. I wouldn’t say it’s popular, but it isn’t completely dead either: there’s at least one active European server that gets full every day. There’s one in the U.S. too. Even the development process isn’t entirely dead. Modders from  The Darkest Hour  team have just released a massive update and they plan to keep improving the game in 2016.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NC3M--ik25U
(video by Joe Smhoe)


Pros (compared to RO2)

Slower pacing. People don’t tend to run around at breakneck speeds quite as much. Twitch reactions are not as important, and this game is noticeably easier to play for me.

Weapon balance. Weapons have a lot more recoil and sway when shooting from standing or crouching position. This means that resting your weapon on random objects for support is very important and players tend to use cover more. Simple bolt-action rifles are incredibly powerful: they do a lot of damage and are significantly more accurate than semi-autos. You can either have good rate of fire or good accuracy (RO2 semi-autos, by contrast, give you both, and an SVT-40 is almost always better than a Mosin). One could argue that this isn’t very realistic, but it makes playing as a rifleman fun, whereas in HoS it can be very hard and frustrating. Or maybe I’m just hopelessly bad at playing rifleman in RO2.

No spawning on squad leaders. You have to actually walk or ride from spawn to the capzone. It increases the value of your life and value of life of your enemies. When you kill someone, he’s not going to respawn in vaguely the same place in 10 seconds. You won’t see him again in at least half a minute (or more for large maps). And it helps to avoid the situation where if you spawn on SL, you're likely to immediately die, but if you don’t, you’re not in the capzone, you’re not helping your team cap, you’re not protecting your SL. Survival in situations like these depends largely on luck: if you happen to spawn behind cover, you’re good, but if you spawn in the open where one of the enemy machine gunners can see you, you’re boned and will have to try again. This can be very annoying in RO2.

Darkest Hour (a mod) has one of the best spawning mechanics I’ve seen in this type of game: MDVs (Mobile Deploy Vehicles). Basically, an MDV is an APC with a spawn point inside. You can park it anywhere, but it’s bulky and noisy — hiding it behind enemy lines can be tricky. When you spawn in it, you can have a look around and hop out when you think it’s safe-ish. Or, if it clearly isn’t, you can try moving it to a better position. It’s vulnerable to satchels, panzershrecks and whatnot, so the chance to die immediately after spawning is still there, but at least it’s not random and it’s very rare.

No stat grinding or unlocks. When you start playing, your weapon is identical to the ones used by players who have played this game for years. They won’t have faster running speed, faster reloads or resistance to suppression. Joining a winning team won’t make you level up faster, and blatant team stacking is fairly rare. Most matches feel more balanced.

No UAVs. You can use vegetation and ruined buildings to hide for a long time and nobody’s going to find you unless they see or hear you. Unfortunately, people can still fly around as spectators when they’re waiting in a spawn queue. There’s a mutator that blacks out the screen when the player is dead, but most servers don’t run it nowadays.

Plenty of large combined arms maps with open design, including some really huge tank-centric maps. There’s an achievement for destroying a tank at 2000+ meters. And popular servers actually run these: it’s not like Counter-Strike or TF2, where there are thousands of community maps available, but most servers stick to stocks like de_dust2 and cp_dustbowl.

Huge variety of weapons and vehicles. You can play as Soviets, Germans, Americans, Brits, Australians, Canadians, Romanians, Italians, Hungarians, Poles and Finns. Some of the vehicles included: BA-64 (aka the clown car), Panzer II Flamm and OT-34 (flamethrower tanks!), ISU-152 (152 mm self-propelled gun), Sturmtiger, Sturer Emil, Marder III Ausf. M, SdKfz 234/2 “Puma”, BMW R71 motorcycle (with or without sidecar), ZiS-3 truck, Willys and Volkswagen Kübelwagen, STZ-5 (although it’s used as an infantry transport) and even a farming tractor. Not to mention a good number of Italian and Hungarian tanks (even World of Tanks doesn’t have these). There are AT and FlaK guns, boats, planes you can paradrop from, mortars you carry around and setup wherever you like. You can also use tanks to transport infantry.

Tank crewmen can get out of their vehicles and get back in. It adds immersion, allows you to park your tank in a safe place, get out and gather intel with your binoculars (silhouette of a person with binocs is nowhere near as noticeable as a tank on the horizon). It also makes it possible to bail out and continue fighting on foot or join a different crew when your tank is damaged. Tank crew frantically getting out of a burning tank is something you’ll never see in RO2.

Team-tanking is fun and useful, whereas in HoS you’re often better off with bots even if you use voip. It’s just faster to press W and have your tank move forward immediately. In RO:Ost, it is faster to switch to driver and press W too, but you won’t be able to reload the gun at the same time. Or keep an eye on the enemy. So, a fully crewed tank with voice comms is likely to outmaneuver a solo tanker, which isn’t true in RO2.

I love the way you have to turn the tank turrets using keyboard, not mouse. Having to control each axis separately is more immersive than just pointing at the target with a mouse cursor. It feels more like turning two separate cranks.

Your character won’t give away your position by making random loud remarks while you’re trying to sneak.

There are doors you can open and close. Even Wolfenstein 3D had this feature, but RO2 doesn’t.

Cons (compared to RO2)

Low population.

Automatic weapons arguably have too much recoil and are hard to use.

Weaker physics. Bullets and shells don’t penetrate objects. Vehicles can occasionally get stuck on flimsy obstacles like picket fences.

Nonadjustable sniper rifle scopes.

No squads, no fireteams, no tactical view. You can’t mark enemies on the map.

Many of the really cool features are only available in  DH, and most popular servers for this mod are in the U.S. (high pings for players from Asia).

Tank interiors are not as detailed, there’s no animation for individual crewmen.

No way to kick people out of your tank if you don’t trust them.

No Japanese, no maps set in the Pacific, no jungle. No flamethrowers for infantry, swords, booby traps.

Every character on your team has the same voice, and the number of lines they can say is very limited.

P.S. I’m not saying Red Orchestra 2 is a bad game, it’s definitely worth getting too.

reviewText:
Hands down my favorite first person shooter of all time. Run and gun rambos need not apply.

Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time then you will have a pouch full of half full mags.

You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath.  Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing. Its better while crouched and even better while prone or rested on an object. The is no magical zoom button. What you see is what you see unless you have an optic.

Theres nothing like having your weapon shot out of your hands as you run to take cover behind some sandbags. Then wondering if you should risk going back to try to retrieve it or wait and try to find a weapon from another fallen soldier.
The graphics are dated and the bots are very dumb, but the multiplayer gameplay is still so good it makes up for it. The tank warfare can be fun too but much of my time was spent with my boots on the ground.

Steam only shows 41 hours on record for me on this game but I had many hours on this game prior to when steam began tracking game time. So many late nights. The thrill of a short range firefight between 2 rifleman, both run dry and with no time to reload they rush to stab or butt-stroke(lolz) the other. So many great moments with nothing but an M44 in my hands and some panzerfausts I had found laying about as I waited to ambush a passing german tank. I had so much fun playing with the humble bolt action rifles I ended up buying a real M91/30 and M44. I was mighty fond of that lovely SVT40 though......

reviewText:
What sets this apart from other multiplayer co-op first person shooters? A strong emphasis on realism and historical accuracy.

The closest comparison to this game might be Enemy Territory: Quake Wars, but Team Fortress and Counterstrike are in the same genre. Basically you've got two teams and you've got to attack/defend various objectives within a time limit. But those other games are far more forgiving; if you get shot you can just use a medkit, if you get a baddie in your crosshairs just pull the trigger.

Well, in Red Orchestra there are no crosshairs for most guns, and there is no health regeneration. If you get shot even once you're probably dead. Expect to die a lot in this game. Fortunately the respawn times are short!

Other realistic aspects include significant recoil and reload times for most guns. In Team Fortress you'll be spraying bullets everywhere without worrying about aiming or ammo. In Red Orchestra you've got to make every bullet count, because there's no auto-aim and ammo is limited. Even if you end up with a machine gun you'll get much better results firing short controlled bursts rather than spraying bullets everywhere. Realists rejoice!

There's a large number of maps to choose from, all of which are based on or at least inspired by real World War 2 battles between the Germans and Soviets. A great amount of work went into making sure the uniforms and equipment were historically accurate, and even that the interiors of the tanks looked realistic.

TANKS! Yes, there's more tanks than you can shake a stick at in this game. Tanks are very hard to destroy and can easily mow down waves of attacking infantry, but they are not invincible. On many maps the gameplay will involve trying to destroy the other team's tanks, or getting your own tanks to the objective.

Tank armor is strongest in front, weaker on the sides, and weakest in the rear. So a lot of tank battles involve trying to sneak up on enemy tanks from the sides or rear. It helps that tank crews have a restricted field of view, so it's easier than you might think to ambush them!

There are some other vehicles too but they are mostly transports with a secondary anti-infantry role.

The realism may put off some players. As a WW2 history buff I know that a Tiger tank is much better than a Panzer III tank, but a casual gamer offered the choice of getting into one tank or another couldn't be expected to know that. The fact that there are so many tanks and they mostly look alike compounds the problem, although it is realistic.

Did I mention this game is complicated? There's a key to fix a bayonet to your rifle, a key to change the barrel of your machine gun if it overheats, a key to pop open the hatch of your tank to get a better field of view...need I go on? Expect a steep learning curve.

My main complaint is that teams can become unbalanced rather easily. A game with 8 players vs 6 will see the smaller team struggling to survive. I guess I got spoiled by the auto team-balancing mechanic of ET:QW and TF; I just always assumed a game in this genre would have it. On some servers bots can be substituted for people to balance teams, but bots are a bit of a wild card. They can be awesome marksmen as infantry, but they're hopeless when driving any kind of vehicle.

There is no single player component. The soundtrack is appropriate and non-intrusive. I got this game practically for free in a sale; buy it if it's $5 or less.

If you're a World War 2 history buff or you liked Enemy Territory: Quake Wars then you'll like Red Orchestra.

I waited a week or so to get this, as my graphics card is a little too old to run the second.
And let me tell you what, that week or so was well worth it.
For a eight year old game, this is one of the best shooters i've ever played.
Aiming down the sights is a must, rifles have to be re-bolted after every shot, a few bullets can kill etc.
Tanks feel very natural as well, you're either a driver, gunner, or a machine gunner, there's no be all end all position in said tanks. The driver and gunner have to work in perfect unison to survive against another tank and reloading times can be a killer.
The maps are big, without feeling too oversized.
I've yet to play the Darkest Hour modification but am downloading it at this moment.

If you can't run the second, or missed out on the free day I highly reccomend spending the 10 bucks on this. Even if the servers aren't as populated, graphics a tad out dated and some other very minor things, you won't be dissapointed.

reviewText:
If you like World War 2 first person shooter PVP simulations, this is a good game to get.  This game is more on the realistic side of WW2 combat, but using location capture and ticket loss.   Although the graphics are outdated, still a good game.  The problem is the player community is low, and not many servers active now.  It is popular in Europe still.

You will be using authenically modeled weapons with iron sights. There are no crosshairs, hard to tell friend from foe and has friendly fire.  Has a compass, ammo and body status on UI,  has fatigue that limits movement , and has no healing.  Some infantry classes are Limited in number, while plenty of soldiers with bolt action rifles available.  Has artillery strikes called in by a radio located at major bases.

You can drive a tank solo by jumping between crew stations.  But if driving a tank with AI bots onboard, the bots get in the way, when in tanks.  Tanks are modeled as close to real thing. There are more tank models available to drive on some maps. If you are playing with bots on server, they are stupid.  Cannot order the bots around either.

Also download the Darkest Hour, Mare Nostrum, Real Panzer mods to this game for more Red Orchestra goodness.  The modding community has made more maps for this game.

Does have Steam Achievements but you can only do them on a Stats Enabled server with more than 15 player.  Has badge trading cards.

Needs more people playing and more servers hosted.

reviewText: Starting as a mod Red Orchestra won the contest at Moddb.com and won a license for their engine, which is what you see in the retail version. It has been significantly improved over the years, the bugs were ironed out and new maps came, and occasionally are still delivered by the community. There aren't many players yet the battles can reach an epic scale of a maximum of 50 soldiers per map. It's a game thar needs more time investment then Call of Duty or Battlefield in order to learn all of it's mechanics. The maps are huge in comparisson to Battlefield(not as huge as ArmA's or Operation Flashpoint - that's a nigtmare). Oftenly you'll be running to the control point for 10 minutes just to be pinned down by some sniper hiding in the woods or a building, whatever you prefer. There are also vehicles in the game which are most effective when teamwork and trust between the crewmembers is applied(yes you need more people to drive and shoot at the same time). PC gaming is changing with RO.

The emphasis of the fighting gameplay is rooted in gritty, challenging, tense realism rather than the flashy superficial blandness of so many recent and better-known military shooters.\n\nAlthough there aren't many servers on Steam with a high number of only human players as opposed to bots, the ones that exist will provide you a gripping multiplayer battle experience. One of the best, most innovative games ever made.

reviewText: Red Orchestra is notable for its emphasis on realism in comparison to other World War II-based FPS games. The game takes place on the Eastern Front of World War II and covers the period from 1941 to 1945. The player is given the opportunity to participate in the reconstruction of events in the Red Army and also for the Wehrmacht. The game is targeted primarily at the network mode, but there is a single-player game against bots. Each location (map) is a really existing historic district. Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45 features an advanced ballistics system for both small arms and tank rounds - incorporating bullet drop, flight time, and tanks with more realistic armor properties than most games (featuring: penetration and deflection, in relation to range and projectile trajectory angle).

reviewText: I'm not a huge fan of music games that don't let you import your own music (Guitar Hero, Rock Band, Guitar Hero World Tour, The Beatles Rock Band, Guitar Hero II, Rock Band II, etc.) but Red Orchestra is a winner in my book because you just conduct an orchestra playing classical music, which I really enjoy. It has all the classics (that was a pun!) like Tchaikovsky, Mozart, Bach, Beethoven, and (unfortunately) Wagner, and it also has some more snappy modern stuff like Shostakovitch, Mahler, and stuff Mozart wrote when he wasn't 12. I feel like this would have been better as a Wii game or a Kinect game or something, because using the mouse to conduct feels weird, but it does support joysticks and frankly it's so well done that I don't see why anyone would complain. A must for fans of music games who, like me, want something other than Coldplay or Freezepop to listen to.

reviewText:
This game is HARD.

If you want realistic eastern-front WW II action, this is your game. No artificial zoom in on iron sights, no med packs, no mercy. EVERYTHING will kill you. Get shot in the arm? Hope you weren't planning to shoot a rifle. Shot in the legs? No more walking. Caught crossing in front of a tank with your tank's side exposed? BBQ tonight! The only place where ths game isn't realistic is that you can't snipe a guy on a motorcycle. You can, however, blow him to bits.

This isn't to say that the game is impossible. You are rewarded for employing battlefield survival techniques by being alive for a few minutes longer.

The tank battles are glorious, but some of the larger maps tend to involve you driving for ten minutes to your death.

A sequel is bound to come out soon, but several servers are still up and running.

reviewText: Awesome Simulator, also great for gamers who can't afford a gpu. Played fine before I got one plays even better now, & all in all a wickedly real game

Solid gameplay I haven't seen in a long time. The only downside is its terribly dated graphics - I'd hold out for RO: Heroes of Stalingrad running on the UT3 engine.\n\nUnlike other WWII FPS games that rely heavily on automatic weapons, RO goes back to basics with bolt-action rifles for about half of each team and they have a distinct advantage over SMGs at about more than 10 feet. It sounds dull but makes it really intense. Tanks, artillery, and machine guns weren't left behind either.

Red Orchestra deals with the Ostfront (East Front) of World War II. Play as the Russians or the Germans in a realistic matchup with up to 50 players.

One shot will kill you. Bolts needs to be manually reloaded. There's no run and gun found here. Moving from cover to cover, and suppression fire from teammates are the only way for success.

Machine gun fire will cause players to search for cover or immediately fall to a prone position. In Red Orchestra, players will team up to work together to flush a sniper from his position.

If you're looking for a realistic, team-based first person shooter, than Red Orchestra has it.

This game is surprising for a FPS in that it is mostly accurate. There's no crosshairs to make life easy for you - you're aiming as the soldiers did down iron sights. This adds an air of realism, and you will likely find yourself going to favourite weapons.

No single-player campaign, which many may consider a downside, but the immersive multiplayer levels (and there are so many more you can download) make up for it. There's also a practice mode, but the AI is the usual brand of stupid, especially at operating tanks. (Though their aim when they do manage to shoot at you is uncanny)

The tank warfare may be slightly different from reality to even things out, but the change enhances the game.

Highly recommend.

My favorite feature is the ability to rest your weapon on any object in the game world for more accuracy and stability. I find it a lot better than some ridiculous sticky cover. Everything You do influences Your weapons accuracy: Your stance, Your character`s fatigue, Your health, etc. If you try to shoot when your hands are wounded, you`re tired from sprinting and you`re in an upright stance, then you`ll probably miss because of huge weapon sway.

Red Orchestra is generally pretty awesome but the WW2 theme starts to get tiresome after some time. I wish there was a modern day combat mod for this :(

Important note: This game is not very popular, and sometimes it`s hard to find servers with people on them. The game also enforces some serious restrictions when choosing a class ( for example: There can be only 1 or 2 snipers in each team ) so be prepared to fight as a bolt action rifleman when joining a server with many people on it.

The game offers a single player vs AI training mode, which is useful to learn about the maps but the bots themselves are appallingly useless.

The realism of this game is great though, only in ARMA 2 have I been more afraid of dying! It is very exciting to play, and can involve some great teamwork:

You spawn, you run to the nearest half-track, joining your comrades in the back you speed through the fields towards the front. Artillery rains down around you. An enemy tank is seen in the distance and fires. Bailing out the smoking vehicle, you dive into the hedge. Crawling along this, you meet a support trench that takes you closer to the action. Bullets zip above your head. Where are they coming from? You wriggle up to a fellow machine-gunner, and resupply him with ammunition. Whilst he changes the smoking barrel, you fire off a few rounds with your semi-automatic rifle to keep their heads down. More friendly riflemen join you. Fixing your bayonet, you leap out of the trench and sprint towards the nearest building. A bullet catches you in your hand, causing you to drop your rifle, leaving you defenceless. You pause momentarily, and an enemy sniper hits you. Cue shot of your body falling to the ground. Repeat x many.
But was it fun? YES

The original Red Orchestra that some may not have heard of. Personally, I think this game is almost perfect in its execution and complexity for a game released in 2006. There is so much content in this game: tons of maps and tons of weapons and vehicles; more than Red Orchestra 2. This is comparatively not a bad thing - as Red Orchestra 2's focus is on infantry rather than on combined arms combat as the first game is.

The graphics may not be excellent, but it portrays the game's hopeless feel. You are a single soldier fighting amongst up to 63 other players in World War II. Death is inevitable, and the game's gloomy, dark feeling adds to the atmosphere. That is not to say that a single soldier cannot do anything by himself, however. If he is good, then he will be able to provide a large influence in the battle.

It is a shame that this game does not have many players. Personally, I have found great difficulty getting into the game as the only populated servers are inhabited by Russians who seem to only play this game. Thousands of hours they have poured into the game; they know everything about it, and they will annihilate poor little me (with 60 hours at time of writing) without a second thought.

This game is unforgiving, and that is the reason why it is so fulfilling. There are no visual aids; no silly unlocks like in Red Orchestra 2 (grr, I hate that unlock system) and you will die in one hit. The wound system mostly works and portrays the weakness of a soldier to a bullet well, but I have had times where I have been shot by a full calibre rifle and not died.

The tanks... they are interesting. The game attempts to hide the HP system of the vehicles, but it does not work. Typically, your tank will only take one shot before being destroyed. Some tanks are objectively better than others (why would you take a StuG III if you can use a Panzer IV H?).

Apart from that, I think the game is balanced. The submachine guns are impossible to use at long range (this is probably on purpose - but it has been changed in Red Orchestra 2), which personally annoys me. Therefore, the most viable weapon is the bolt-action rifle. You can never go wrong with one.

I have not mentioned the excellent mods. Darkest Hour: Europe 44-45 is the most prominent one... in fact, the only mod that is played. It is based on the Western Front after Operation Overlord, so it provides a refreshing experience and change from the Eastern Front for Ostfront 41-45. Also, I think the tank gameplay is better.

There is also Mare Nostrum, but nobody plays that one. Therefore, I have not had a chance to play it, but its premise seems interesting. North Africa - the British against the Germans and the Italians. A game based on a setting that I have not seen before.

In conclusion, I think that Red Orchestra Ostfron 41-45 is well worth your time. It is the best WWII shooter I have played (apart from Red Orchestra 2; I'm not sure which one is better) and perhaps the best shooter I have played ever.
Please buy it, because I don't want to see it die before Rising Storm 2 releases.
